So, we have got sufficient business experience that we can operate in different systems, whether it's fully integrated business as we have in some markets or where we are only involved in some parts of the business. So that is not really an issue for us. As far as gas is concerned, the are no talks on the gas grid. So, there we expect that we will continue in the integrated business model.

In German, the second question in from Simon is, in German generation plus the plant 4.8 gigawatts cell, from this transmitter, does EON put itself at a competitive disadvantage by reducing its market share to around half that of the largest player? Johannes?

We are not at half of the market, the biggest market player to begin with. Let's assume we are around 24%. It will always varies if you look on capacity or output or what number you take, but let's take for granted it's around 24% and we move around 20. And RWE as the biggest market participant is, in the same way of calculation probably around 30. The next one behind us is significantly smaller than us. So, doesn't make a hell of a difference strategically if you are 24 or 20, especially if you built new capacity. While we talk, I don't think so and we understand the way we act any how has not abusing market power in any way. And if you don't do that and if you follow integrated market views and run your business according to market signals, it shouldn't make any difference and we don't foresee that it makes any difference. Obviously, we have less investment in that market and we will redistribute some of that. But from a strategic point of view I don't foresee any significant strategic change.

Next question comes from Vincent De Blic from Cazenove. First question, what was your average achieved generation price in 2007 from Central Europe West power, for 2006, you had said 42 megawatt hour. Is it therefore €52 per megawatt hour?
The answer is clear. Yes, I can answer that question, 52 euro is okay.
"How do you explain the difference with RWE's reported 47 megawatt hour for 2007?"
I'm not going to answer that question, ask my friends at RWE.

"Second, can you elaborate on the increasing competition in Pan-European Gas midstream. What is it driven by?" The answer is increased throughput volume by the third parties they're putting in in the gas business.

And last, the third question. "Just a clarification on slide number four of Mr. Bernotat's presentation, is your new investment plans, 63 billion total, or 63 billion in 2008-2010 plus 6 billion post-2010?" To answer first, I think we've already answered that. 63 in total Marcus do you want to comment? No, I think we already talked about that.

The next one is our friend Lueder Schumacher from Dresdner. "You stated that you have not changed your power price assumption in your 2010 target. Given that, power prices were about 55 euros per megawatt hour. When you first mention that target" in May 31 he means, "and that you see tight reserve margins and new entry cost at 70 euros per megawatt hour. Isn't that the outlook based on your assumption that you are too conservative?" Marcus?

I mean -- look we've -- I don't think -- I mean, I don't want to comment on whether it's too conservative or not. To me what is relevant is, when I look at the forward rates, currently for the different markets in 2010, Central Europe that's around 62 and Nordic is around 51. Then basically I would say, yes we continue to be south of those of numbers. Luede has mentioned the number as high as 70 euros there, we don't exactly see that for baseload. We still feel comfortable with our projection, mathematically given we have not yet sold all of the 2010 volume, all things being equal, yes then there is some upsides. But I mean, what do I know what the power prices in 2010 are going to look like going forward? We will manage that position and then we will have to see in the end where we come out.

I think what is relevant to people here is that we feel comfortable that the 12.4 number we put forward, we just didn't create that number by making some ludicrously high assumptions as it relates to prices at which we might sell our generation volume. We are -- as it stands today probably a bit conservative on that end, but I mean the situations may change, we've seen very drastic movements in power prices in the U.K. wholesale market, so I think we all don't know what exactly the prices will look like in 2010.
Yeah, that is a good point, we've obviously also seen in particular coal be very expensive, so in fact, just looking at the spreads, we don't see that big upside in the different markets.

The next question comes from "Regarding German market, how much of the 2008 production have you sold already? What kind of price changes are you experiencing?" And I think it was shown on the backup page from Schenck's presentation on page 21, how much we have sold in Germany and U.K. but we can answer, 90% sold in Germany. Regarding the price is concerned I think Marcus already mentioned just lately. Second question, "when you said 10 million investments in Nissan, does this include minorities?" I think we are -- in the current -- in the middle of the negotiation, and will not comment on the details.
Yeah.

The third is, "how do the new transmission revenues compared to those of 2007 as opposed to those proposed by new regulation?" Marcus? New transmission revenues compared to those of 2007 as opposed to those proposed by you regulation?

The revenues might be slightly up even, because we have higher volumes, their relative price for the transmission services are slightly down. But if you compare our numbers to the numbers of some competitors, we think we got out -- we came out somewhat more positively, I would say. If you compare that to our expectations and to what we think should be the right result came out somewhat, as Marcus said, a little more negative than we thought should be the results. But much more we can't say at this given time.

Thanks Johannes. Next question come from Peter Bisztyga from Citi. "How much of the 1 billion euro target operational improvement can we expect to contribute to 2008 adjusted EBIT. And what will be the level of restructuring costs impact on, impacting on 2008 adjusted EBIT, first question?"

I can't give an answer to that question. Part of the 1 billion that we communicated back in May last year was also an improvement in gross margin. So there is too many detailed effects that will some how also find its ways through to some extent into the 2008 number. But we don't have the details there.

The second question from him is, "will all of the one time effects in Central Europe in 2007, page 5 of the Schenck's presentation reverse out in 2008 or will some item for example cost allocation consolidate effects will be ongoing." Marcus?

Okay, the -- costs, the reallocation of costs of 200 million that I was referring to in terms of a charge to Central Europe and a sort of an income at the consolidation slash corporate center level. That will continue to be in place. We obviously do not expect another change in the nuclear power provision resulting from an adjustment to our financing structure. I mean, we have adjusted it and we don't expect – we will not change our financing structure in the course of 2008. The know that some of that may reoccur -- or will reoccur in 2008. What the overall amount is going to be will depend on when the plants come back on stream and the 223 million provision that we've built. Yes, we do not expect that to reoccur in 2008. And as far as the, what is called consolidation effects mainly as concerned we clearly expect that number to come down in 2008.

Thank you, Marcus. Next question comes from from EXANE BNP Paribas. Question, "could you please elaborate on the discussions you're already having with the U.K. government regarding potential funding of fuel poverty scheme? Are you threatened as first suggest to be imposed a claw back?"

I think, those discussions have just started; it's a big political issue in the U.K., probably driven by the desire of the politicians to react to do something about the increases the market has seen in the recent months. And as far as I learned it was triggered by a rather, let's say unprofessional presentation by Centrica that sparked off the whole discussion, unfortunately -- but it's too early to have any assessment what it might end up with. But it sort of sounds to me like a typical reaction of politicians trying to jump on the political issue, showing some action, and whether there will be a result of the debate remains to be seen, but certainly there is no clarity at this stage.

Thank you, Wulf. The next question, the last one from Internet is, if I don't say correctly, . Could you please tell me what is going to happen with current OGK-4 management, are you satisfied with it? Second, when OGK-4 strategy will be disclosed? What are the perspectives of gas business development in Russia for E.ON? Lutz?

So question number one, we are extremely happy with the performance of the current management. No reason to change anything in that regard. Strategy of not OGK-4 but of E.ON in the Russian power market is worked out whilst we speak and we will probably have a chance to disclose more of that, if we want to – towards the end of this year. And the third question, Kiran, to be honest I didn't really get it. Was that about us entering the gas business in Russia?
What are the perspectives of gas business development in Russia for E.ON?
Well, I think nothing has been considered in that regard and I am not sure whether we want to compete with the state monopolist Gazprom in the Russian gas market.
Thank you, Lutz. The next question here in the hall is Christopher Rogers [JPMorgan]. Chris?

Yes. A further couple of follow-ups. Firstly, could you just tell us what your achieved price in the Nordic region was in '07, if that's possible please? And secondly I noticed from your usual EVA analysis that you've increased your weighted average cost of capital. Could you just explain why you've done that, for where you have done that? And also whether there is any impact on the remuneration of management as a consequence, I know that's been a measure – that EVA has been a measure in the past.
Christopher, do you mind to repeat that WACC increase for overall general you're saying?

Yeah. No, I was just looking at the table that you put into the annual report with the EVA analysis, the cost of capital has been put up for a number of the divisions at the grid level. I'm just wondering why that is and whether that has an impact on remuneration in any way given that EVA I know has been a benchmark measure for you in the past?
Okay. Nordic for 2007 average price realized is 34 euros and I think the way I understand your question is we – is it just on the remuneration of people or was that a question on the WACC?
It was kind of both. Why have you moved the WACC.

Okay. We have changed the weighted – the WACC, but we did that quite frankly already back mid last year, because we wanted to adjust it to what is really our target capital structure. And bear in mind in the past we had always worked from a I believe 55% assumed debt portion of the capital structure, which was not exactly reflecting where E.ON was back then. And we have also furthermore adjusted the cost of capital to reflect a higher beta compared to what we have in the years before, what we had in 2006. So all these changes were introduced, again they were introduced back in May. Clearly quite frankly this is something we will have to take another look at I would say sort of in the second half of this year in light of the fact that we have obviously, since May last year seen another shift in the capital markets, and we will have to see what that means for how we should think about our cost of capital, but it's too early to speculate on what that is going to imply, we will have to do the analysis. As far as the remuneration is concerned, you may want to comment?
Yes, I mean there is no direct link of the WACC to the individual remuneration or bonus schemes of our managers. So that is a total unrelated issue.
Okay. So the remuneration continues to be based principally on EBIT...
That's the EBIT targets, which we are agreeing with our market and business units, and therefore also it's being further broken down to intermediate level of our senior management.
Thank you.
There is some ROCE impact, but it is not influenced in any way by this change. So, let's say not a single dime to anybody on this table or any other table due to this change, not a single one.

Thanks. I have questions from from Goldman Sachs on Internet. Question, "has the level internal competition for the growth CapEx led you to see upside to the returns spread and/or the medium-term earnings from the growth. Do you see upside for the – to the 100 billion – 100 basis points spread?" Marcus?

First of all the 100% bps spread that we were referring to back in May was related to the organic investment plan on the generation side. We – I mean – I don't have visibility now here on all the projects included in the investment plan. What is clear is that we in fact do have by now a much higher competition in fact whenever someone comes up with a new investment proposal, she or he has to at the same time come up with a suggestion on which other projects we should just strike out from the existing investment plan. So that inevitably will lead to the fact that any new thing being proposed almost by definition has to bring a higher spread compared to the average of the existing projects. And, so in that sense – but I can't point to, this or that specific project, we clearly see a greater discipline in us taking investment decisions and quite frankly, already in the way people put forward investment proposals.

The second question from is a long one, I had to take a breath in to read it. "In your chart, you showed the upside to power of prices based on new build economics. Around what level of power prices is your medium-term earnings target based and what will trigger you to increase the power price assumptions you use in your internal guidance to align them with increases you're signaling in your generation presentation?"

I mean where I think I've commented on that when answering Lueder's question on power price assumptions for 2010. We are reviewing our own assumptions on an annual basis. Quite frankly, we are right now in the midst of doing that again, but at this stage, there is no reason to change it. And as far as our generation presentation is concerned, what it is trying to work out is that in fact for the short-term, new entrance cost has come up. There is not always a short-term link between what is new entrance cost and what are the wholesale prices in the market. There can be a time delay, I mean over time, theoretically, they obviously have to somehow converge, but we're talking here about the time period until 2010. And today, as I said before, we don't see a need to adjust our numbers. We will review them on an annual basis and if we feel or if we see that there is a major change that should be introduced, we will do that and then communicate it to you.

The next question is from Lueder Schumacher [Dresdner Kleinwort]. Question, "the components you have secured for new power plants, how long are the prices you secure valid for, and does it matter where the project is completed?"

It doesn't matter where the project is completed. I think we have quite good context on that, that for most of the significant components we are not depending on the location. The first part, location is not important. What was the other one?
For how long?
For how long?
How long?
That varies between components, and obviously, also not very smart to announce everywhere, where they might be an opening coming up at some point. I don't think it's wise to discuss that.

Okay. The next question comes from from Société Générale. "Regarding the funding of the investment plan, would you consider using some of the large amounts of E.ON's liquid funds on balance sheet? What would be the optimal level of liquid funds on balance sheet? Thank you very much.

There is still some liquidity we can use. People shouldn't forget that some of what we show as liquidity is in fact assets under management on balance sheet that are backing both pension provisions that you see and also some of the nuclear decommissioning provisions. I don't have and would not want to give the specific breakdown in terms of how much liquidity we believe we can still use of the – whatever the specific number now is, 1 billion that you can see on the balance sheet. But again, it's – quite a significant portion of that is assets that are backing pension obligations and nuclear decommissioning obligations.
And the last and the final question from . Question, "what was the reason for the change in the discount rate from 4.5% to 5% and therefore the decrease in the pension liabilities?"

This is something we have to do every year. There is a certain method by which the interest rate that should be used when calculating the pension obligation, that then has to be applied. It effectively looks at a quasi risk-free rate and then adds to that a certain spread to reflect, I believe it's a AA corporate rated bond. And we have seen compared to December 2006, an increase in both in sort of the quasi risk-free rate on the one hand and then – I mean that is obvious also in the spreads that are being charged for corporate rated bonds and those two effects together just technically translate into a 100 basis point increase on the interest rate.

Thank you. And I hit my deadline 4:20 exactly, I was expecting. On behalf of analysts and investors, I like – we like to thank Wulf and Marcus, Johannes and Lutz for helping us and talking to you directly. Second thing, we like to thank you for coming to Dusseldorf despite the strikes and problems in transportation. Third, thanks for joining all on Internet and don't forget to thanks all our colleagues sitting here in the back, the people's knowledge of helping us. And we see you again, and as I said, we will have a presentation on the numbers and we will let you know as soon as possible. Thank you all for coming on behalf of the management. Wulf, would you like to say something?

Just to join in thanking you for coming and showing an ongoing interest in our company and being so patient to stay with us during this conference and all the questions coming via the Internet. See you again in individual meetings or group presentations or whatever and take care. Thank you very much.
Last one thing I forgot to say, we will have drinks and to eat outside a little bit so you can chat with the management and this is a time, use it. And see you again. Thanks.
